study_plan_entry.title: CCMX Advanced Course 'Atomic Force Microscopy (AFM): Theory and Practice' (Empa Dübendorf)

free_text.Content: [li]Introduction to AFM and its application to different research areas of interest to PhD students and researchers from industry.[br/][li]AFM principles and applications in bioscience.[br/][li]Best practices and improvement of the participants' AFM experience in the laboratory, focusing on AFM operation modes including contact mode, intermittent contact mode, true non-contact mode in vacuum, peak force, high speed AFM, and, measuring different tip-sample forces including shortrange forces, van der Waals forces, electrostatic (Kelvin) forces, and magnetic, forces.[br/][li]Properties that can be measured, including surface topography, surface roughness, phase contrast (material contrast), spectroscopic measurements (force/distance curves).[br/][li]Combination of AFM and ToF-SIMS techniques.[br/][li]Hands-on practice with instruments supplied by Bruker, NanoScan and Nanosurf (Nanosurf easyScan2 FlexAFM System).[br/]
